section.title: Section 1.7 - Introduction to Continuity and Limits

worksheet.exercise:
Are the following functions continuous?
f(x) = \left\{ \begin{matrix} x & x \leq 1 \\ x^2 & x > 1 \end{matrix} \right.
g(x) = \left\{ \begin{matrix} \frac x{\left\vert x \right\vert} & x \neq 0 \\ 0 & x = 0 \end{matrix} \right.
Yes, it is continuous
No, it is not continuous

Find k so that the following function is continuous on any interval: f(x) = \left \{ \begin{matrix} kx & x \leq 3 \\ 5 & x > 3 \end{matrix} \right.
While I use Desmos for intuition, to find the exact answer we need the left and right sides to meet when x=3. Thus we need k(3)=5 and hence k=\frac 53.

Let f(x) = \frac{e^x - 1}{x}.
Make a table of values of f(x) for x=0.1,0.01,0.001,0.0001,-0.1,-0.01,-0.001,-0.0001.
Make a conjecture (educated guess) about the value of \lim _{x\to 0} f(x) .
Graph the function on your graphing calculator to see if it verifies your conjecture from parts a) and b).
We see from both the table and the graph that f(x) approaches 1 as x approaches 0. Hence, \lim_{x\to 0} f(x)=1

section.title: Section 1.8 - Extending the Idea of a Limit

worksheet.exercise:
Compute \lim_{x\to \infty} \frac{4x+5}{6x^2+7x+8}
You can evaluate this graphically, but to me the best tactic is to divide the numerator and denominator by the largest power of x. In this case that is x^2. \lim_{x\to \infty} \frac{4x+5}{6x^2+7x+8} = \lim_{x\to \infty} \frac{\frac4x+\frac5{x^2}}{6+\frac7x+\frac8{x^2}} = 0 Note that everything in the numerator goes to zero, so the fraction as a whole goes to zero (as the denominator is nonzero).

Compute \lim_{x\to 2} \frac{x^2-4}{x-2} using any technique. Justify your answer.
While any of the solutions can be used here, the algebraic technique is the best choice. \lim_{x\to 2} \frac{x^2-4}{x-2} = \lim_{x\to 2} \frac{(x-2)(x+2)}{(x-2)} = \lim_{x\to 2} x+2 = 4

Compute \lim_{x\to 0} \frac{\sin x}{x} using any technique (making sure that your graphing calculator is in radians). Justify your answer.
Here, the algebraic technique cannot be used, so we will use graphical and numerical. From the graph and the table, we see that the limit approaches 1.

worksheet.exercise:
A raindrop falls from a cloud with height (in meters) given as a function of time by h=1000-4.9t^2. Find the velocity and acceleration at time t.
The velocity is the derivative \frac{dh}{dt} = -9.8 t \text{ m}/\text{sec} and the acceleration is the second derivative \frac{d^2h}{dt^2} = -9.8 \text{ m}/\text{sec}^2

So we know that \frac{d}{dx} ( \sin x ) = \cos x \hspace{.2in} \text{ and } \hspace{.2in} \frac{d}{dx} (\cos x) = - \sin x and we know that \tan x = \frac{\sin x}{\cos x} . Compute the derivative of \tan x.
Using the quotient rule, we get \frac{d}{dx}\left( \tan x \right) = \frac{d}{dx}\left( \frac{\sin x}{\cos x} \right) = \frac{\cos(x)\cos(x)-\sin(x)(-\sin(x))}{(\cos(x))^2} = \frac{(\cos(x))^2+(\sin(x))^2}{(\cos(x))^2} = \frac{1}{(\cos(x))^2} The last equality comes from the Pythagorean Identity.

From problem 62 in section 3.5 The voltage, V, in volts, in an electrical outlet is given as a function of time, t, in second by the function V = 156 \cos(120 \pi t)
Give an expression for the rate of change of voltage with respect to time.
What is the maximum rate of change?
\frac{dV}{dt} = 156(-\sin(120\pi t))(120\pi)
The maximum that -\sin(120 \pi t) can be is 1 as -1 is the minimum of the sine function. Thus, the maximum of the derivative here is 156\cdot 120\pi.

Compute the following derivatives:
\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx} (\sin(x^2))
\displaystyle\frac{d}{dx} \left( \frac{3\cos(x)}{x^2-7}\right)
\displaystyle\frac{d}{dx} \left( \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)} \right) (p.s. Do you know a name for this function?)
\displaystyle\frac{d}{dx} \left( e^{\sin(x)} \right)
\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx} (\sin(x^2))= \cos(x^2)\cdot (2x)
\displaystyle\frac{d}{dx} \left( \frac{3\cos(x)}{x^2-7}\right)= \frac{(x^2-7)(3(-\sin(x)))-(3\cos(x))(2x)}{(x^2-7)^2}
\displaystyle\frac{d}{dx} \left( \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)} \right) = \frac{\sin(x)(-\sin(x))-(\cos(x))(\cos(x))}{(\sin(x))^2} = \frac{-1}{(\sin(x))^2} (the original function is cotangent)
\displaystyle\frac{d}{dx} \left( e^{\sin(x)} \right) = e^{\sin(x)}\cos(x)

Compute \frac{dy}{dx} if \ln x + \ln (y^2) = 3.
Taking the derivative of both sides of the equation we get \frac 1x + \frac{1}{y^2}\cdot 2y \cdot \frac{dy}{dx} = 0 Solving for \frac{dy}{dx} we get \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{-y}{2x}

Find the equation of the tangent line to y^2 = \frac{x^2}{xy-4} at the point (4,2).
There are several approaches here, but let's start with some algebra so that we can get rid of the fraction. y^2(xy-4) = x^2 xy^3-4y^2 = x^2 Taking the derivative of both sides we get x(3y^2)\frac{dy}{dx} + y^3 - 8y\frac{dy}{dx} = 2x Solving for \frac{dy}{dx} we get \frac{dy}{dx}(3xy^2-8y) = 2x-y^3 \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{2x-y^3}{3xy^2-8y} We want to compute the tangent line at (4,2), so we plug in 4 for x and 2 for y. \left. \frac{dy}{dx} \right\vert_{(4,2)} = \frac{2(4)-2^3}{3(4)(2^2)-8(2)} = 0 Since the slope is zero, the tangent line is y=2 as that is the y-coordinate of the point.

Find the slope of the tangent to the curve \sin (xy) = x at the point (1, \pi/2). (Hint: Look at the graph to explain the answer.)
First we take the derivative of both sides \cos(xy)\cdot \left( x \frac{dy}{dx}+y\right) = 1 Using algebra to solve for \frac{dy}{dx} we get \frac{dy}{dx} =\frac{\frac{1}{\cos(xy)}-y}{x} Plugging in the point, we get \left. \frac{dy}{dx} \right\vert_{(1,\pi/2)} = \text{ undefined} Looking at the graph you find that the slope is vertical at this point explaining the undefined slope.

Use the tangent line approximation of f(x)=\ln(x) at x=1 to approximate the value \ln(1.1).
Using tangent line approximation at x=1 we see that f(1)=\ln(1)=0, f'(x) = \frac 1x, and f'(1) = \frac 11 = 1, so the tangent line is y = f(1)+f'(1)(x-1) = 0 + 1(x-1) = x-1 Using tangent line approximation we see that \ln(1.1) = f(1.1) \approx 1.1-1 = 0.1

Let f(A) represent the price of building a house of area A ft^2 in Bob the Builder's subdivision. To buy a 2100 ft^2 house it costs $200,000. If f'(2100)=90, estimate the cost of a 2150 ft^2 house using tangent line approximation.
Using tangent line approximation we get f(A)\approx f(2100)+f'(2100)(A-2100) = 200000+90(A-2100) f(2150)\approx 200000+90(2150-2100) = 204500. The bigger house should cost approximately $204,500.
